awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Towards mmWave-based Vehicular Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
A new wave of industrial revolution is being witnessed, where vehicles evolve from being controlled by human beings to fully autonomous cyber-physical systems. Having connected vehicles that can communicate with each other, as well as with highway infrastructure and management, is vital to the success of such revolution. Therefore, the goal of this proposal is to design vehicular communications and networks that can provide high data-rate, low-latency, and security. Towards fulfilling this goal, the millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency band will be utilized as the fundamental enabler to achieve the required high data rates for vehicular communications. The proposed project will benefit the global society by helping to realize safe and secure self-driving cars. 

The main challenges facing the design and validation of the proposed vehicular communication system are spreading across the implementation of mmWave Radio Frequency (RF) front-ends, baseband processing, and the network management. The design of mmWave RF front-ends requires high-gain and low-profile antenna array for inconspicuous integration on the vehicular platforms, RF beamforming techniques, and finally low-cost, hardware-reduced, and power efficient electronics behind the antenna array. At the baseband processing level, the main obstacles include physical layer secrecy, RF impairment mitigation, and enabling simultaneous multi-vehicle to infrastructure communication. Finally at the network level, novel network architectures are needed to enable low-latency and fast local decision making. The proposed research is transformative as it will advance fundamental knowledge in: 1) High-data-rate RF transmission over mmWave through the design and validation of mmWave multiple-antenna transceiver architectures along with RF beamforming schemes that exploit both spatial and spectral diversity; 2) Enhanced physical layer processing through the design and validation of digital beamforming schemes that achieve physical layer secrecy, mitigate RF impairments, and achieve high-data-rate simultaneous multi-vehicle communication; and 3) Edge computing via a low-latency dynamic network management architecture by utilizing the emerging SDN paradigm, which involves intelligent nodes with local decision and machine learning capabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has laid down several foundations for vehicular communication, which is a vital step towards benefiting the global society by realizing safe and secure self-driving cars. The developed communication devices and protocols in this project have achieved high data-rate vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication over millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency band, while guaranteeing low delay and secure connections. The intellectual merits of this project first include developing communication devices with complete reconfigurable transmitter and receiver architecture, to enable V2V communication over both the Dedicated Short Range Communications (DSRC) band at 5.9 GHz and mmWave band at 28GHz. The developed devices include a reconfigurable Radio Frequency (RF) frontend with high gain antenna arrays and beamforming capability to compensate for pathloss at the mmWave frequency band. Secondly, the intellectual merits include designing low-delay and high-data-rate communication protocols for various V2V scenarios including coexisting V2V communication with radars and cooperative relaying networks with mobile roadside units. Thirdly, a vehicular network with a software-defined network (SDN) architecture at its core, has been developed to eliminate network layer routing. To this end, we extended the Openflow SDN module for the widely used NS-3 simulator to integrate DSRC, LTE and 5G and made it publicly available. Such SDN-assisted vehicular network was tested for maintaining safety in the use case of self-driving truck platooning. In developing the aforementioned protocols, some novel approaches have been employed, such as: a) reinforcement learning models for tracking the communication parameters of moving vehicles, b) full-duplex transmission for doubling the data rate, c) Blockchain technology for optimal pairing of communicating vehicles, and d) reconfigurable intelligent surfaces for enabling coexistence between radar and V2V communication and also for increasing wireless security. The broader impacts of this project include providing the research community with developed transmitters and receivers, for V2V communication at DSRC and mmWave bands, and also an SDN-based vehicular network testbed in NS-3. Finally, many of the developed machine learning models and optimization frameworks are applicable to other challenges in wireless communication, as well as to other disciplines.
